One of the very first drugs that showed promise

It reduced the amount of virus in cells grown

But in a small clinical trial,

Labs then started to test old compounds

It was called azidothymidine, or AZT.

It had been a candidate for

Now, it seemed to keep HIV-infected cells

Excited scientists rushed AZT into trials

Although the trial had a lot of flaws,

had more T cells and
were much less likely to die.

In March of 1987, the FDA approved it, making
AZT the first AIDS drug in America.

But it was not cheap, and it came with a bunch

nausea, heartburn, insomnia, and heart and
liver damage.

AZT works against HIV because

the enzyme that copies the

But AZT also does something

Doctors eventually realized that a lower dose

After a while, the levels of virus in the

And that’s the major challenge

It develops resistance to drugs really easily,

Most of the time these mistakes

Over time, and with selection, HIV will mutate

In 1996, doctors started giving

Patients started living longer.

The levels of virus in their blood

Today, it’s often just called

We now have dozens of different drugs

This is the breakthrough that changed HIV infection

It’s also helped with preventing the spread

Not only does that make the

The reality is, as good as antiretrovirals

That’s why many researchers still want to

There are two main types of potential cures:
a sterilizing cure and a functional cure.

A sterilizing cure is what you would think
of as a cure: total eradication from the body
with absolutely no virus left.

With a functional cure, on the other hand,
the person would basically be in remission.

They could stop taking antiretrovirals, but
somewhere, deep inside them, they’d still
have a small amount of the virus.

Most researchers are focusing
on a functional cure

because it turns out a
sterilizing cure is extremely difficult.
In fact, it’s only happened for one person:

a man named Timothy Brown,

He was HIV-positive and also had leukemia,

HIV uses a surface protein called CCR5 to

Doctors gave Brown chemo and radiation to

Technically, we don’t know for sure if he’s

Now, as amazing as that procedure was, scientists
